biogHist.abstract: Renwick was established by Department of Community Services in 1976, using the buildings and land that had been occupied by the Mittagong Cottage Homes and Mittagong Training School for Boys. Renwick was a home for dependent children (state wards) of all ages and both sexes. It closed in 1994 and was sold to developers. Some of the cottages remain, but the site has been subdivided.
biogHist.p: The name Renwick honoured Sir Arthur Renwick, the first President of the State Children's Relief Board, who had established the Mittagong Cottage Homes in the late 1880s.

Renwick was formed from the buildings that had been Mittagong Cottage Homes and the Mittagong Farm Homes. Like them, it was organised on the cottage principle, with house parents living in with the children. The cottages were:
Suttor
Linden
Hayden
Rotherwood
Garran
Goodlet
Waverley
Jefferis
Delauret
Mackellar
Challenor
Rowe
The cottages and outbuildings were a mix of older buildings dating from the 1880s and 1890s. Purpose-built cottages were added from 1900 until the 1970s. There were two schools, Southwood and Toombong, and a hospital, jam factory, dairy and sawmill. According to Kathie Bezer, a former resident, Garran and Rotherwood became co-educational homes in 1976.
The Renwick site was sold by the New South Wales Government to Landcom, and in 2013 was being subdivided and developed, resulting in substantial loss of buildings.
In 2014 members of the Mittagong community and former wards were trying to preserve surviving buildings for use as a children's museum and youth centre.

chronItem.event: Location - Renwick was situated at Mittagong

descriptiveNote.p: Renwick used the buildings that had been Mittagong Cottage Homes.
